Her symptoms started a couple of days ago with cough that is
occasionally productive, rhinorrhea, sore throat and wheezing.
She denies any fevers/chills, nausea/vomiting, diarrhea or
dysuria. She has occasional chest and abdominal pain when she
coughs. She says she notices the wheezing but she does not feel
that she is short of breath or that she is having difficulty
getting enough air in, except maybe on exertion. 

The wheezing has been getting progressively worse and her
daughter noticed it was loud when talking to her on the phone so
went to ___ today for evaluation. She was sent in to the ED due
to concern for stridor. 

On review of outpatient notes, looks like her home torsemide has

visiting nurse yesterday stating that patient has had a new 
cough
productive of clear phlegm, new wheezing and Tmax of 99 at home.

to

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ female with history of Atrial 
Fibrillation on Apixiban, Sick Sinus Syndrome status post 
Permanent Pacemaker, Chronic Kidney Disease and type 2 diabetes 
mellitus recently started on insulin admitted with cough, 
wheezing, sore throat, recent leg swelling and weight gain, and 
was found to have significant hypoxemia. Her presentation was 
felt to be most consistent with viral bronchitis +/- reactive 
airway disease. She was treated with prednisone and her symptoms 
improved. She was also re-started on torsemide 10 mg PO QD, 
which she tolerated well. Overall picture seems consistent with 
a viral bronchitis overlaid upon a chronic HFpEF with possible 
chronic/subacute worsening of volume status. ___ evaluated her 
and recommended home with outpatient ___, and when she was 
symptomatically improved, she was discharged home.

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES:
====================
[ ] Patient to perform daily standing weights at home 
[ ] Needs outpatient Cardiology f/u in ___ weeks for further 
eval/mgmt of HFpEF and titration of torsemide dose.
[ ] We stopped her home HCTZ on admission given hyponatremia and 
normotension, this was not resumed at discharge. 
[ ] Patient should have a repeat electrolyte panel done at her 
next PCP ___ visit to ensure she is tolerating resumption 
of torsemide without electrolyte abnormalities or renal 
dysfunction.
[ ] Patient prescribed an albuterol-ipratropium inhaler PRN at 
discharge in case she develops wheezing in the future.

Discharge Instructions:
Mrs. ___,

___ was our pleasure caring for you at ___ 
___.  You were admitted to the hospital with 
shortness of breath, wheezing and cough that we think were most 
likely caused by bronchitis, possibly from a viral infection.  
You improved with conservative treatment including nebulizers, 
cough medicines, and a short course of steroids.  Your blood 
sugars were elevated because of the steroids, but they will go 
back to normal once you complete the course of steroids 
(prednisone).

We also found that you have evidence of increased fluid in your 
lungs and ankles from your heart failure, so we re-started a 
medication you had been on previously (called Torsemide) at a 
lower dose than you had previously been on, and we are stopping 
your hydrochlorothiazide.

You should weigh yourself every day at home.  Call your doctor 
if your weight goes up or down by more than 3 pounds in a day or 
by more than 5 pounds in a week - this may indicate that we need 
to change the dose of your Torsemide.

It was a pleasure caring for you and we wish you a full and 
speedy recovery!

Sincerely, 
The ___ Medicine Team
